Question 1: Which of the following is not included in the format of the death certificate recommended by 
the WHO?

options.c: Other significant conditions contributing to death
options.d: Age of person at the time of death

questions.explanation: Age at the time of death is not included in the WHO format for a death certificate.

questions.question:
Question 2: You are filling the death certificate of a patient who died from rupture of the myocardium 
following an acute myocardial infarction. This was because of thrombosis in the coronary 
artery due to longstanding atherosclerosis. What will you record in line I (c) of the death 
certificate?
questions.explanation:
Coronary artery thrombosis is to be filled in line I (c) of the death certificate as one of the 
antecedent causes in the order of the events that took place. The flow of events in this patient is as follows: 69 
Sold by @itachibot As per the recommendations of Forty-Third World Health Assembly 1990, an additional line (d) 
was added below (c) in part I of the death certificate, as approved by the WHO. Part II will only be filled up with a significant condition contributing to the death but not related 
to the disease or condition causing it.

questions.question:
Question 3: An HIV positive patient was suffering from multi-drug resistant tuberculosis. He died of 
respiratory failure due to lobar pneumonia. Which of the following options is the most 
appropriate for the line I (a) of the death certificate?
questions.explanation:
Lobar pneumonia is appropriate for line I (a) of the death certificate. Line I (a) consists of the 
immediate cause of death such as the disease/condition. Immediate cause is the 
immediate/terminal event leading to death In this patient: • I(a) - Disease directly leading to death: Lobar pneumonia • I(b) - Antecedent cause: MDR tuberculosis. • II- HIV Respiratory failure is a mode of dying in this patient. It is not the cause of death. Terminal events like circulatory failure and respiratory failure, are modes of dying. They should 
not be written as the immediate cause of death in the death certificate because they are just signs 
of death. Simply put, respiratory failure is 'how he died' whereas lobar pneumonia is 'why he died'. 
Therefore, lobar pneumonia (why he died) is the cause of the death. 70 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 4: 60 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following is not a morbidity indicator?
questions.explanation:
Years of potential life lost is not a morbidity indicator. It is a mortality indicator. It is the years of 
potential life lost through premature death. Notification rates, spells of sickness and incidence are examples of morbidity indicators.

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following statements about rate is false?

options.a: It measures the occurrence of an event in a population.
options.b: It has no specification of time.
options.d: It's numerator is mostly part of the denominator.

questions.explanation:
Rate is the measurement of the occurrence of a particular event in a given time. Hence, rates have 
a specification in time. Examples include crude death rate, incidence rate etc.

questions.question:
Question 6: To calculate the crude death rate of a country, at what time of the year is the population 
assessed?
questions.explanation:
The crude death rate is a mortality indicator, which uses the mid-year population as its 
denominator. The mid-year population is always attributed as the population on 1st July of any 
year. Hence for calculating the crude death rate, the population is assessed on the 1st of July.

questions.question: Question 7: For which of the following purposes is age-specific death rates not used?

options.a: Identifying specific age groups at risk
options.b: Comparison for different causes within the same population
options.c: Comparison between different sexes in relation to accidents
options.d: Comparison between different age groups in relation to accidents

questions.explanation:
Sex-specific death rates are used for the comparison between sexes and not age-specific death 
rates. 71 
Sold by @itachibot Age-specific death rates are used for: • Comparison for different causes within the same population. • Comparison between different age groups in relation to a particular event. • Identifying specific age groups at risk.

questions.question:
Question 8: 61 
Sold by @itachibot An epidemiologist is assessing an outbreak of acute diarrhoeal disease in a region. He wants 
to predict the virulence of the causative agent. Which of the following parameters will he use 
for this purpose?
questions.explanation:
Case fatality rate is used in this scenario as it is the most useful parameter to predict the virulence 
of an acute illness. It represents the killing power of disease. Note: Case fatality rate is an incidence proportion and not a true rate as no time interval is used for its 
calculation.

questions.question:
Question 10: A village has a population of 30,000 people. 500 of them contracted a disease X, out of which 
75 died. What is the case fatality rate?
questions.explanation:
Case fatality rate is given by the formula: The total number of cases of disease X= 500 The total number of deaths= 75 Hence the case fatality rate= 75/500 x 100 = 15% 72 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 11: In a village of 5000 people, an outbreak of cholera led to 200 cases with 50 deaths. What is 
the case fatality rate?
questions.explanation:
The case fatality rate is 25%. Case fatality rate: (Total number of deaths due to a particular disease)/(Total number of cases due 
to the same disease)x 100 : 50/200 * 100 = 25%

questions.question: Question 12: Which of the following is the simplest measure of the burden of a disease in a community?
questions.explanation:
The proportional mortality rate is the simplest measure to estimate the burden of a disease in a 
community. It is commonly used for broad disease groups and when population data is not available.It is of 
limited value in making comparisons between populations and in identifying risk groups.

questions.question:
Question 14: Standardisation was done before comparing the mortality rates of two countries. What is the 
rationale behind this?

options.a: Due to difference in number of deaths.
options.b: Due to difference in age distribution.
options.c: Due to difference in the population density.
options.d: Due to difference in cause of death.

questions.explanation:
While comparing the mortality rates of two countries, the standardization of rates is done due to 
differences in age distribution. The two types of standardisation include direct and indirect. In both methods, a standard population is chosen where the numbers in each age and sex group 
are known and its choice is arbitrary. The commonly used standard populations are the Segi world population and the European 
standard population.

questions.question: Question 15: Which of the following statements is false about the standardized mortality ratio?

options.a: It is a form of direct standardization.
options.b: Observed deaths and expected deaths are part of its formula.
options.d: It can be used if the event of interest is occurrence of disease.

questions.explanation: Standardized mortality ratio is a form of indirect standardization.

questions.question:

those who ate fruit salad, 55 developed food poisoning. What is the attack rate?
questions.explanation:
The attack rate is calculated by the formula: 74

questions.question:
Question 17: Out of a family of 4 members, one of them developed COVID-19 infection. Four days later, 2 
other members developed the same. What is the secondary attack rate?
questions.explanation:
Secondary attack rate is calculated by the following: In this scenario, there is one primary case. The total exposed contacts are the other 3 members of 
the family. The number of persons developing the disease is 2. 75 
Sold by @itachibot So, secondary attack rate = 2/3 x 100 = 66%. Note: The primary case is excluded from both the numerator and denominator.

questions.question:
Question 18: Which of the following study designs would you prefer for calculating the incidence of a 
disease?
questions.explanation:
The study designs which can be used to calculate incidence are cohort studies and longitudinal 
studies.

questions.question: Question 19: Which of the following statements about incidence are true?
questions.explanation:
Incidence is not affected by the duration of the disease. Analysis of incidence rates may provide 
useful insights into the effectiveness of the health services provided. Incidence is the number of new cases occurring in a defined population during a period of time. Prevalence is more than incidence as it is the product of incidence and duration. Incidence is a type of rate and not a proportion.

questions.question:
Question 20: A medical officer noticed that there were 300 new cases of cholera in an area in a year. The 
total population in that area is 30,000. What is the incidence of cholera?
questions.explanation:
The incidence of cholera is 10 per 1000. Incidence is given by the formula: In this scenario number of new cases = 300 Total population = 30,000 Hence the incidence rate = (300/30,000) × 1000 = 10 76 
Sold by @itachibot Therefore it is 10 per 1000 per year.

questions.question: Question 21: Which of the following is a good indicator of efficacy of health programs?
questions.explanation: Incidence is a good indicator of the efficacy of health services and programs.

questions.question: Question 22: Which of the following is false with regard to prevalence?

options.a: It is a product of incidence and duration.
options.b: It can be determined by a cross-sectional study.
options.c: It is an example of rate.
options.d: It is point prevalence unless specified.

questions.explanation:
Prevalence is a proportion, not a rate. Prevalence is the proportion of all cases, old and new, of a particular disease at a given point in 
time or over a period of time in a given population. It can be determined from cross-sectional 
studies. Types of prevalence: • Point prevalence is the prevalence at a point in time. Usually, prevalence is point prevalence 
unless otherwise specified. • Period prevalence is the prevalence over a period of time.

questions.question:
Question 23: The incidence of a disease is 4 per 1000 of the population with an average duration of 2 years. 
What is the prevalence?
questions.explanation: The prevelance in the given situation is ‘/1000 population. Prevalence is given by the formula : Prevalance = Incidence x Mean Duration Prevalence = 4/1000 x 2 = ‘/1000 population

questions.question:
Question 24: A village has a total population of 100,000 with an under-16 population at 3%. The 
prevalence of goitre in the under-16 population is (0.3/100). What is the total number of 
under-16 population affected by goitre?
questions.explanation:
The total number of persons in the under-16 with goitre is 9. Number of total under-16 population = 3% of 100,000 = 3000. Thus, total number of goitre patients who are under-16 with the prevalence at the given value = 
3000*0.3/100= 9

questions.question:
Question 27: A randomized control trial showed an effective treatment against an infectious disease. It was 
then incorporated by the health system. Which of the following is subsequently expected to 66 
Sold by @itachibot happen?
questions.explanation:
A new effective treatment for infectious disease would reduce the duration of the disease, thereby 
reducing prevalence. Note: Both prevalence and incidence decrease but prevalence is the first to show a change in 
pattern. Hence, ‘prevalence decreases’ is the better answer.

questions.question:
Question 28: There was an outbreak of hepatitis A infection in your town. Proper prevention strategies 
were enforced. What is expected to happen at first to the number of cases of hepatitis A?
questions.explanation: In the given scenario, prevention of hepatitis A would lead to decrease in incidence at first. Prevention of an acute disease would prevent new cases, thus first decreasing incidence.

questions.question:
Question 29: A new drug was approved for the treatment of prostate cancer. It has been shown to prevent 
early deaths but not cure the cancer. What is expected to happen to the cases of prostate 
cancer over a period of time?

options.a: Increase in incidence, no change in prevalence
options.b: Decrease in incidence, increase in prevalence
options.c: Increase in incidence, decrease in prevalence
options.d: Increase in prevalence, no change in incidence

questions.explanation:
A new drug that prevents death yet does not cure the disease will cause an increase in prevalence 
but the incidence remains the same. In the given scenario, the drug reduces early deaths but does not cure prostate cancer. Hence, 
there is a paradoxical increase in the prevalence while the incidence remains the same. Prevalence depends on two factors, the incidence and duration of illness. If the population is 
stable and incidence and duration are unchanging, the relationship between incidence and 
prevalence can be expressed as: P = I X D (I - Incidence and D - Mean duration) This equation shows longer the duration of the disease, the greater the prevalence. Note: • In chronic diseases like TB, prevalence will be higher than incidence. • If a new treatment for a disease is effective, incidence does not change but prevalence 
decreases as the duration of disease decreases. • If the treatment only prevents death but doesn’t cure the disease, it may cause a paradoxical 
increase in prevalence.
